HotKeyEvent Class Reference

#include <HotKeyEvent.h>

Inheritance diagram for HotKeyEvent:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

The event that a hot key has been entered.

Hot keys represent special characters e.g. to easily access fields (e.g. indicated by underlined characters). The input handling of the adapter instantiates this class and adds them to the desktop's event queue by using its addEvent() method.

See also:
Desktop::addEvent()

Definition at line 23 of file HotKeyEvent.h.

Private Attributes

char character1
 The first character that has been entered, using the ISO-8859-1 encoding, or 0, if this character is not valid.

bool  released,
int  repeats,
char  character1,
char  character2
) 
 

Creates a new hot key event.

Parameters:
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
scanCode The scan code of the key that caused the event.
held Whether the key is currently held down.
pressed Whether the key is newly pressed down.
released Whether the key has been released.
repeats The number of key repeats.
character1 The first character that has been entered, using the ISO-8859-1 encoding, or 0, if this character is not valid.
character2 The second character that has been entered, using the ISO-8859-1 encoding, or 0, if this character is not valid.

virtual void executeOn (  EventTarget *  target  )  [protected, virtual]
 

Executes (handles) the event on a given event target.

The default implementation does nothing and returns false.

Parameters:
target The event target to execute the event on.

Reimplemented from KeyEvent.
